Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 12:28PM PinkyLee wrote: I had drains up to four weeks after bi/later with expanders.  I was very easy when they came out.  One came out on its own around week two/three.  The doctor remove the next one the same week and on the four/fifth week the last two came out. It was a lot more comfortable for me once they were out.
Posts.Title: Getting the drains out robinri CathyMcD

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 02:00PM PinkyLee wrote: Thanks for the response.  Virginia Beach is about 4 hours away.  So that wouldn't work.  Maybe I can work on starting a group near where I live.  I really want to find something positive to do once I make it through this situation.  How do I pm RoseG?
Posts.Title: Looking for support group and exercise PinkyLee AnneW

Posts.Content: PinkyLee wrote: Good afternoon: I am in the process of waiting prior to having my exchange.  My next appointment with the ps is on January 5.  I live about 50 miles outside of Washingon, DC, near Manassas, VA.  I am looking for a cancer support group and exercise class expecially for breast cancer patients.  Since my surgery I have had very little energy, still have difficulty sleeping and experience pain along the side of the breast.  I also have nerve pain in my back where the muscles came from for the reconstruction. I would like to start getting my life back.  First, I know that I need some support because I keep thinking that this disease is going to come back.  My younger sister lost the battle after two rounds of different treatments.  This is a very difficult time of year for me because she died on December 14th right after she had us put up the tree and decorate the house.  I have been wanting to get in the holiday spirit, but I can't get out of my pajama's.  If anyone knows of a group in the area, please let me know.  I can't keep feeling like I do.  I realize that recovery is part mental, and right now I am losing the mental battle.  Lord, give me strength to make it to the end of this long journey Dx 2/13/2004, LCIS, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 1 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Looking for support group and exercise PinkyLee AnneW

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 09:01PM PinkyLee wrote: Thanks Rose for your response I had my surgery at Prince William Hospital.  I had checked with them and they may be starting a support group.  I live very near Fauquier County Hospital so I will see what they have.  I was hoping that I could find something like the survivor exercise groups that I have read other members talking about.  This is my second time dealing with cancer.  I had lumpectomy and rad in 2004 just before my sister lost her battle.  I have been told that I am cancer free, but that doesn't always help.  I am so tired of people telling me how lucky I am and would love to talk to others that understand my fears and my concerns.  I see you live in the DC area, did you use Suburban Hospital?  I went to a workshop there one weekend a couple of years ago.  I really need to start getting out and doing something other than sitting here in my pajama's waiting for the next surgery.
Posts.Title: Looking for support group and exercise PinkyLee AnneW

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2008 08:50AM PinkyLee wrote: Kimmy, Make sure you protect yourself and don't leave your house.  I am sorry that you have a man that could be so insensistive.  Don't trust his back peddling.  If he could be calus enough to say it in the the first place, I would not trust him. Please don't hide in your room to make his life easier.  You are the one suffering, if he is a little unhappy, big deal.
Posts.Title: gripe - hubby not happy... kimmytoo pee

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2009 09:15PM PinkyLee wrote: LOL:  I have a decon at church who ask for weekly updates on my product in construction.  I think if he could get away with it he would ask for a feel.  He started asking my cousin's prior to me coming back to church how they looked.  Sunday after exchange he said:  okay turn to the left, now right; how are developing.  I laugh because we have small church and he himself is a cancer survior.  But I kind off pisses me that he would have that much interest in my boobs.  Other woman look and if it is in a proper place, I have pulled up my shirt and say :"see what cancer can do, but I am working on new perky boobs, when did you have a mammogram"  they soon change the subject.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2008 09:53PM PinkyLee wrote: I didn't read all of the postings but I was wondering if you may be forming a key loyd.  (forgive my spelling)  Before my surgery my surgeon asked me if I had ever had that problem before.  When I had my lumpectomy, I formed a hole in the top of my breast, but I didn't have the ridge problem.  My sister did, and they had to finally remove the area so she could wear a bra. I hope you get better, this is the last thing you need after dealing with this demon.  Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Just Wondering....After Lumpectomy shelteringtree KAK

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 06:37PM PinkyLee wrote: Firsts I say to you good luck. I watched my baby sister go through treatment without talking to her children openly about what she was going through.  How old are your children?  I would suggest that you be as open and honest with them as you can.  You will be surprised how supportive and understanding children can be. My sister was 35 when she was first diagnosed.  She decided not to have her breast removed and she had a recurrence less than 5 years later.  She fought hard to hold on to her breast and by doing so allowed the cancer to spread.  If there is a chance that it has taken root, remove your entire breast. When your daughter gets older, make sure she is tested.  Also, you can have the genetic testing done to see if you have the gene
Posts.Title: Surgery Next Week Ness78 kerry_lamb

Posts.Content: PinkyLee wrote: Hello, I am scheduled to have a bilateral mascetomy on September 23 with reconstruction being started at that time.  I know that this is necessary, but I feel so afraid. I can't sleep well and find myself crying a lot.  Everyone around me keeps telling me that I am not looking at this from a positive view point, but I truly am trying to.  I am afraid of how I will look and how I will be preceived sexually once I have this done.  I also want to know how long it will take for me to be back to my life.  I am 52 and have just graduated from college with the desire to start a new life.  Now this has knocked me down for a minute, but I need to know when I can expect to get back up. Also, can anyone suggest a support group in the northern virginia area  Lord, give me strength to make it to the end of this long journey Dx 2/13/2004, LCIS, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 1 Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 06:24PM PinkyLee wrote: thanks for the tips.  I live near Warrenton, VA.  If anyone knows where that is.  I am very thank ful that I located this group.  The reading and tips that I have found so far have made me feel a little better.  I have been thinking about getting some type of medication to help me along.  I saw a store this afternoon in Gainesville called "I'm still me.  Has anyone hearad of it? I also think that one thing that is contributing to my anxiety is that I watch my younger sister go through this surgery, but she lost the battle two years later.  I realize that I am undergoing surgery earlier in the process than she elected to.  She was very afraid of losing her breast.  I try to keep a positive outlook, but like you all have said this is really big!  and really life altering. Hey - another question:  I am an African American woman and have been concerned about what to do with my hair.  I won't need chemo, but I know that I won't be able to do much with it for a while.  I have been considering getting it braided, does anyone have any other ideas other than cutting it all off.
